headline: Delta, United, Other Airline Stocks Fall on Trump’s Credit-Card Plan. Why It’s Overdone.
summary: Delta  United and other airline stocks were falling early Monday as investors assessed President Donald Trump’s call for a 10% cap on credit-card interest rates.  Airlines make billions of dollars in revenue each year from co-branded credit cards.  Delta said it received $2 billion from American Express in the third quarter alone, up 12% year-over-year, driven by co-branded card growth.

headline: Meta Needs So Much Capital It Hired Its Own Banker
summary: Meta Platforms  announced on Monday that Dina Powell McCormick, who comes from the worlds of international finance and politics, has become the company’s president and vice chairman.  The move signals Meta won’t slow its enormous artificial-intelligence data center buildout soon.  As a child, McCormick came to America as an Egyptian immigrant who spoke no English.

headline: ‘Biotech Super Bowl’ Lands With a Thud. Stocks Slide on Lack of Deal News.
summary: Monday is the first day of  J.P. Morgan’s  annual healthcare investor conference, which draws thousands of investors, analysts, and executives to San Francisco each year.  There is ample precedent: Last year,  Johnson & Johnson  announced a $14.6 billion deal to acquire Intra-Cellular Therapeutics on the first day of the gathering.  The Wall Street Journal reported last week that Merck was in talks to buy the biotech Revolution Medicines for roughly $30 billion, but as of late morning, no such agreement had been announced.

headline: Why Moderna Stock Is Dropping After Good News
summary: Moderna  offered investors a glimpse at its upcoming earnings report as it pre-announced revenue above the midpoint of its prior guidance range.  Presenting at the annual J.P. Morgan Healthcare Conference on Monday, Moderna said it expects 2025 revenue of roughly $1.9 billion, $100 million above the midpoint of the range communicated on the company’s third-quarter earnings call.  The company still expects revenue growth of up to 10% in 2026, and reiterated that it expects non-adjusted operating expenses to decline to $4.9 billion from a range of $5 billion to $5.2 billion in 2025.

Morgan healthcare conference on Monday,  Moderna  said it expects 2025 revenue of roughly $1.9 billion, $100 million above the midpoint of the range communicated on the company’s third-quarter earnings call. headline: US Bank Shares Tumble as Trump Slams Credit Card Rates
summary: The comments increase the political pressure on a slew of card issuers, including JPMorgan Chase & Co., Capital One Financial Corp. and Citigroup Inc.
